ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Improved quantitative analysis of Cu(In,Ga)Se2 thin films using MCs+-SIMS depth profiling

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The chalcopyrite semiconductor, Cu(InGa)Se2 (CIGS), is popular as an absorber material for incorporation in high-efficiency photovoltaic devices because it has an appropriate band gap and a high absorption coefficient. To improve the efficiency of solar cells, many research groups have studied the quantitative characterization of the CIGS absorber layers. In this study, a compositional analysis of a CIGS thin film was performed by depth profiling in secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) with MCs+ (where M denotes an element from the CIGS sample) cluster ion detection, and the relative sensitivity factor of the cluster ion was calculated. The emission of MCs+ ions from CIGS absorber elements, such as Cu, In, Ga, and Se, under Cs+ ion bombardment was investigated using time-of-flight SIMS (TOF-SIMS) and magnetic sector SIMS. The detection of MCs+ ions suppressed the matrix effects of varying concentrations of constituent elements of the CIGS thin films. The atomic concentrations of the CIGS absorber layers from the MCs+-SIMS exhibited more accurate quantification compared to those of elemental SIMS and agreed with those of inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry. Both TOF-SIMS and magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles showed a similar MCs+ distribution for the CIGS thin films.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Traditional solar cells are formed from silicon, are usually in flat-plate form, and generally are the most efficient type of solar cell. Second-generation solar cells are called thin-film solar cells because they are generated from amorphous silicon or non-silicon materials, such as copper indium gallium diselenide (CIGS). Thin-film solar cells based on Cu(In,Ga)Se2 use layers of semiconductor materials that are a few micrometers thick. CIGS thin-film solar cells have been developed for more than 30 years because of their light weight, flexibility, high efficiency, good reliability, and low manufacturing cost [1–4]. The current world-record CIGS device is based on optimized deposition and processing steps for the constituent layers and demonstrates a photovoltaic conversion efficiency of 20.3 % on a laboratory scale [5]. Thus, CIGS-based solar cells are among the most promising devices for large-scale photovoltaic energy conversion. Recently, CIGS has received considerable research interest because of its high efficiency and low production cost when a fabrication method involving the three-stage vacuum co-evaporation of all of the elements is used. An alternative method is a two-stage growth process, in which the Cu–In–Ga precursors are deposited, followed by selenization. This fabrication appears to be the second most favored industrial process for thin-film deposition [6].

The quality and property of CIGS absorber material for high-efficiency solar cells are critically influenced by the deviation of their stoichiometry. The analysis techniques frequently used to determine the stoichiometry of CIGS thin films are X-ray fluorescence (XRF) [7], electron probe microanalysis (EPMA) [8], inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) [9], glow discharge optical emission spectrometry (GDOES) [10], micro-photon-induced X-ray emission (PIXE) [11], and energy-dispersive analysis of X-rays (EDAX) [12].

ICP-AES is a well-established analytical technique for quantitatively determining elements in CIGS thin films. However, the ICP-AES technique requires the dissolution of a film for sample preparation and provides average values. Surface analytical techniques, such as secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS), Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), are widely used to characterize thin films of various types, with each technique having its own advantages and disadvantages. AES and XPS, used with a sputtering ion gun, provide quantitative depth-resolved elemental profiles of films with different compositions [13, 14]. However, AES or XPS peak intensities depend on the various types of matrices and cause errors in quantitative analysis. Furthermore, there is a limitation of sensitivity for the trace-impurity elements. The advantages of the SIMS method for semiconductor applications are well known, including its extreme sensitivity, high mass resolution, high dynamic range, fast analysis time, and low detection limit. The SIMS technique also offers depth-profiling capabilities with a high depth resolution that can be widely used for supporting the development of thin-film photovoltaic structures. SIMS can supply detailed information about the CIGS compositional grading, which is necessary to obtain high-efficiency solar cells. However, the quantitative SIMS analysis of the elements in the CIGS film is difficult because of severe matrix effects [15–17]. Changes in the matrix composition cause an extreme variation of the ionization probabilities of the secondary ions and lead to a nonlinear calibration curve.

To reduce the matrix effect, Cs+ ions were used to bombard the solid surface, resulting in the emission of molecular secondary ions of the MCs+ type, where M denotes an element from the CIGS sample. The association between Cs+ ions and the ion-induced dipole moment of Mo (neutral M atom) causes a strong correlation between MCs+ ion yields and the polarizability of M [18]. Therefore, the matrix effects influence the MCs+ ions generated by Cs bombardment much less because this method was developed to decouple the sputtering and ionization processes [19, 20]. The method was successfully used for the quantitative analysis of III–V semiconductors [21, 22]. Recently, the possibility of a quantitative SIMS analysis for CIGS thin films has been shown using MCs+ clusters. The measurement of MCs+ clusters reduces matrix effects that result from the varying concentrations of In and Ga [23].

In this work, a MCs+ secondary ion measurement was used for the quantification of each element in the CIGS thin film, demonstrating the suppression of the matrix effect in SIMS quantification. The results confirmed that it is possible to establish a solid basis for a quantitative MCs+ analysis by comparing the results obtained using two different SIMS instruments.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: Cu(InGa)Se2 samples were fabricated at the solar cell center in Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST). The CIGS layers of CIGS010-030 were grown on Mo-coated soda-lime glass substrates in a sequential three-stage evaporation process of Ga–In–Se, Cu–Se, and Ga–In–Se. The temperatures of the substrates were different at the second and third stages for the generation of the CIGS layers of CIGS010-030. In the first stage, In and Ga were deposited on the Mo-coated glass substrate at 300 °C in a Se environment. In the second stage, the temperature of the substrate was increased to 540 °C and Cu was deposited onto the substrate in a Se environment. In the last stage, In and Ga were deposited onto the substrate at 540 °C in a Se environment. For the CIGS layers of CIGS040 and CIGS050, the deposition of monolayer CuGaIn metal precursors onto the Mo-coated soda-lime glass substrates was performed by simultaneous RF magnetron sputtering from a CuGa alloy target and DC magnetron sputtering from a pure In target. The reactive heat treatment of precursors was carried out in a rapid thermal process (RTP) system. The annealing time ranged from 2 to 8 min and the temperature was fixed at 550 °C.

Positive-ion time-of-flight (TOF)-SIMS analyses were performed using an instrument from ION-TOF GmbH (Münster, Germany). A TOF-SIMS 5 system was equipped with Bi+ and Cs+ primary ion beam sources. A Bi+ liquid metal ion source (LMIS) was used for the mass data acquisition. The TOF-SIMS depth profiles were obtained in the dual-beam mode. In this mode, two different primary ion guns were used: one for the spectra collection and the other for sputtering. The analysis source was a pulsed 25 keV Bi+ beam, which bombarded the surface at an incident angle of 45° to the surface normal. The target current was maintained at 1 pA pulsed current with a raster size of 100 μm×100 μm. A cycle time of 100 μs was employed for the mass data acquisition. The spectral resolution (FWHM) of the instrument was 10,000 at m/z 29. A Cs+ ion source was used as the sputter gun and 3 keV Cs+ ions bombarded the surface at an incident angle of 45° to the surface. The target current was maintained at 35 nA continuous current for the 3 keV Cs+ ion sources, with a rastered area of 300 μm×300 μm to reduce the influence of the crater edge. These conditions resulted in Cs+ ion doses that were well above the static SIMS limit, and thus were considered dynamic SIMS. All beam currents were measured using a Faraday cup. For compositional analysis, the intensities of the M+ ions and MCs+ clusters were used, where M denotes the matrix components of the CIGS layer (Cu, In, Ga, and Se). The depth calibration was completed by measuring the crater depth with the use of a P-10 stylus profilometer (Tencor, Milpitas, CA).

Magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles were acquired using a Cameca IMS-4fE7 instrument (France). The primary ion source was the Cs+ ion beam. Positive M+ and MCs+ secondary ions were detected as appropriate for the species to be examined. A primary beam of Cs+ ions with an impact energy of 5.5 keV was used at an incident angle of 46° to the surface. Depth profiles were obtained using a high primary beam current (20 nA) with the beam rastered over a 200 μm×200 μm area to ensure homogeneous sample erosion. A non-overlapped isotope was selected to minimize the mass interference and to ensure that the electron multiplier was not saturated. The working pressure in the sample chamber was approximately 6.7×10−8 Pa.

ICP-AES measurements were performed as follows: a Varian 710-ES emission spectrometer was calibrated using an aqueous solution containing 5 % nitric acid and 1 ppm, 5 ppm, and 10 ppm solutions of Cu, In, Ga, and Se. Generally, a standard solution for a calibration of CIGS is prepared with four elements of the CIGS separately. However, there might be a matrix effect from being mixed with the four elements. For the calibration of ICP-AES, we used a solution of four mixed elements consisting of the CIGS as the standard solution, and found the most suitable analytical wavelengths that contained no significant spectral interferences. Individual solutions containing 1 ppm, 5 ppm, and 10 ppm were analyzed by measuring the intensity of the 327.395 nm emission peak for Cu, the 417.204 nm peak for Ga, the 303.936 nm peak for In, and the 196.026 nm peak for Se.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In Fig. 1, the CIGS sample surfaces were investigated through atomic force microscopy (AFM) images. The AFM results showed that the root mean square roughness (R rms) of the CIGS010, CIGS020, CIGS030, CIGS040, and CIGS050 films were 93.0 nm, 113.8 nm, 160.6 nm, 109.7 nm, and 101.1 nm, respectively. The CIGS010 sample had a smaller R rms value than those of other CIGS samples and there were similar SIMS compositions for three different points. Therefore, the CIGS010 film was selected as the reference sample for the quantitative analysis of the CIGS films.
Fig. 1
AFM images (5 μm×5 μm) of the CIGS samples: (a) CIGS010, (b) CIGS020, (c) CIGS030, (d) CIGS040, and (e) CIGS050

The SIMS analytical technique offers the advantages of sensitivity, high mass resolution, high dynamic range, and low detection limits, while retaining high analysis throughput. SIMS provides quantitative depth profiling capabilities with high depth resolution and is widely used for dopant monitoring in semiconductor technology. This capability is valuable for monitoring thin-film CIGS layers, which are promising structures that can lead to higher overall efficiency. Time-of-flight (TOF)-SIMS provides the relative secondary ion intensity profile of the atomic species under consideration as a function of time as an ion beam sputters through the CIGS film. The depth profile of the CIGS010 sample was obtained with a TOF-SIMS instrument to use as a reference sample. Figure 2 shows the elemental depth profile of the CIGS film obtained by a Cs ion beam of 3 keV with an incident angle of 45°. The secondary ion intensities for the ions Cu+, In+, Ga+, and Se+ were recorded. The measured intensities of one specific elemental peak were divided by the corresponding isotope abundance to calculate the intensities of all isotopes. To calculate the relative sensitivity factor (RSF) of each element in the CIGS reference sample, the ICP-AES results were used as the certificated composition of the CIGS absorber layer (Table 1). ICP-AES is a well-established analytical technique used for determining the elements in a wide variety of samples. A sensitive and accurate method has been established for the quantitative analysis of the CIGS thin films by ICP-AES [9]. Depth profiles of the CIGS samples were obtained at three different points of one CIGS thin film. The CIGS030 sample had a higher R rms value (R rms=160.6 nm) and the SIMS depth profiles were slightly different depending on the position of the sample compared to those of other CIGS samples. Therefore, the CIGS030 film showed a larger standard deviation in the atomic concentration than those of other CIGS samples in Table 1.
Fig. 2
Elemental TOF-SIMS depth profiles of CIGS010 reference film presented in (a) intensity and (b) atomic concentration. The data were generated using 3 keV Cs+ primary ion bombardment under dynamic SIMS conditions

The relative sensitivity factors (RSFs) for an element i of the CIGS film were calculated using the following equation: 1
$$ I_{i} / I_{\mathrm{R}} =( \mathit{RSF}_{i} / \mathit{RSF}_{\mathrm{R}} )\times( C_{i} / C_{\mathrm{R}} ) $$

Equation (1) was then applied to these three elements in the CIGS layer: Cu, In, and Ga. TOF-SIMS intensities were obtained by integrating the intensity area between the surface and the interface of the CIGS absorber layer as indicated in Fig. 2. The correct determination of interface depth is important when calculating the composition of the layers. Several approaches can be used to determine the interface location; however, we used the most common method, which uses the point at which the intensity of the species drops to 50 % of its maximum value approaching the interface [24]. The intensity and concentration of Se were chosen as the reference element denoted by I R and C R, respectively.

After the calculation of the RSFs of four elements in the CIGS sample, the elemental depth profiles of the CIGS020, CIGS030, CIGS040, and CIGS050 samples were also obtained by TOF-SIMS. The sputtering depth was calibrated from TOF-SIMS crater depth measurements by means of a surface profilometer. The mean atomic fraction of an element i (X
i ) can be determined using Eq. (2). 2
$$ X_{i} = \frac{I_{i} / \mathit{RSF}_{i}}{\sum I_{j} / \mathit{RSF}_{j}} $$ Converting the ion intensities of each element into atomic concentrations depending on the depth (x) was accomplished with the following equation: 3
$$ C_{i} ( x ) = \frac{I_{i} ( x )/ \mathit{RSF}_{i}}{\sum I_{j} ( x ) /\mathit{RSF}_{j}} \times100 $$ Using the RSFs that were determined from the reference sample, the TOF-SIMS compositional profiles were obtained as shown in Fig. 3. The CIGS040 and CIGS050 samples prepared by the two-step selenization process showed more severe grading distributions of In and Ga ions in the TOF-SIMS depth profiles than those of other elements.
Fig. 3
Compositional depth profiles of (a) CIGS020, (b) CIGS030, (c) CIGS040, and (d) CIGS050 thin films using elemental peak intensities of TOF-SIMS. The data were generated using 3 keV Cs+ primary ion bombardment under dynamic SIMS conditions

In a MCs+-SIMS analysis, the sample surface is bombarded with Cs+ primary ions and the detection of an element, M, of interest is achieved in the form of MCs+ molecular ions. This method was successfully used for the analysis of III–V semiconductors because the MCs+ ion formation is almost insensitive to the instantaneous local surface chemistry of the sample. The TOF-SIMS depth profile of the CIGS010 sample generated with the detection of MCs+ clusters included the intensities of CuCs+, InCs+, GaCs+, and SeCs+, as shown in Fig. 4a. Integrated intensities of one specific MCs+ peak from the designated range in the figure were divided by the corresponding isotope abundance to calculate the intensities of all of the isotopes. The relative sensitivity factors (RSFs) for a cluster of MCs+ were calculated using Eq. (1) with the integrated intensities from TOF-SIMS and the certified concentration from ICP-AES. TOF-SIMS compositional profiles of CIGS020, CIGS030, CIGS040, and CIGS050 using the RSF values of MCs+ are shown in Fig. 5. The atomic concentration (C
i (x)) of the constituent element i according to the depth x was determined from the RSFMCs and the ion intensity (I MCs) of the individual element as indicated in Eq. (3). Figure 5a and b show the typical depth distribution patterns of the CIGS films generated by a three-stage evaporation process of Ga–In–Se, Cu–Se, and Ga–In–Se. Although the sputtered surface layer may contribute to the different stoichiometry in the surface region, a copper-poor and selenium-rich region is often observed at the surface of the CIGS films and has been attributed to the CuIn3Se5 that typically exists at the surface of bulk Cu-poor I–III–VI2 chalcopyrites [25]. In Fig. 5c and d, the In and Ga cluster ions in the TOF-SIMS depth profiles show severe grading distributions that are easily observed in the CIGS thin films produced by the two-step selenization process.
Fig. 4
MCs+ TOF-SIMS depth profiles of the CIGS010 reference film presented in (a) intensity and (b) atomic concentration. The data were generated using 3 keV Cs+ primary ion bombardment under dynamic SIMS conditions
Fig. 5
Compositional depth profiles of (a) CIGS020, (b) CIGS030, (c) CIGS040, and (d) CIGS050 thin films using MCs+ cluster peak intensities of TOF-SIMS. The data were generated using 3 keV Cs+ primary ion bombardment under dynamic SIMS conditions

The four depth profiles in Fig. 5 were compared with those in Fig. 3, and a major difference in the atomic ratios of Se and Cu was observed at the surface regions. Elemental ionization of the Cu ions was very high and that of the Se ions was relatively low at the surface; however, intensities of the SeCs+ and CuCs+ cluster ions showed the opposite trend. This surface effect also negatively influenced the quantitative analysis results from the elemental depth profiles.

Table 2 shows the quantification results of the CIGS thin films after elemental and MCs+ TOF-SIMS depth profiling measurements of the CIGS020, CIGS030, CIGS040, and CIGS050 samples. Using the same calculation process, quantification was also performed using the MCs+-SIMS method. The atomic concentration of each element in the CIGS absorber samples was calculated using the RSFs and the ion intensity (
$I_{\mathrm{MCs}^{+}}$ ) of the MCs+ clusters. As shown in Table 1, the overall compositions of the CIGS absorber films were determined by using the established ICP-AES method. ICP-AES data were compared with the results obtained by elemental and MCs+ TOF-SIMS depth profiles. The atomic fractions calculated by TOF-SIMS using elemental peaks show, in most cases, a significantly larger difference from the ICP-AES certified atomic fractions of the CIGS020, CIGS030, CIGS040, and CIGS050 films than those obtained by TOF-SIMS using the MCs+ cluster peaks. Overall, the compositions of the four CIGS thin films analyzed using MCs+-SIMS and ICP-AES were similar, within 3 at%. The CIGS020 thin film exhibited a smaller deviation from the ICP-AES value than other CIGS samples. This result indicates that the similar grading of constituent elements in the CIGS sample to the grading of the reference sample generated the smaller deviation in the quantitative analysis of the CIGS absorber layers. These improved quantification results show that the analysis of MCs+ secondary ions for the CIGS sample does not exhibit severe matrix effects encountered for atomic ions [19, 20].

Using the same method, the quantification was also performed using a magnetic sector SIMS instrument with a Cs+ ion beam of 5.5 keV. Figure 6a and b show the elemental and MCs+ depth profiles, respectively, of the CIGS010 reference film. Two sets of SIMS sensitivity factors were derived for copper, indium, and gallium using Eq. (1); the SIMS intensities from Fig. 6; and the ICP-AES measured atomic concentrations in Table 1. Depth profiles by SIMS were also obtained for the CIGS020 thin film. The individual data in the original depth profiles were converted into individual atomic fractions from the ion intensities of the element and MCs+ clusters. Figure 7 shows the compositional depth profiles of the CIGS020 sample with the 5.5 keV Cs ion beam, which shows the difference in the relative atomic fraction of each element and the compositional gradients of Ga and In according to the depth. This MCs+ cluster depth profile is the typical depth distribution pattern of CIGS films generated by a three-stage evaporation process of Ga–In–Se, Cu–Se, and Ga–In–Se. A copper-poor and selenium-rich distribution is a well-known phenomenon at the surface region of CIGS films, as shown in the MCs+ cluster depth profiles. However, the elemental depth profiles provide incorrect information regarding the distribution of the element within the surface region (Fig. 7a).
Fig. 6
(a) Elemental depth profiles presented in intensity and (b) MCs+ cluster depth profiles presented in intensity of CIGS010 reference film by magnetic sector SIMS
Fig. 7
Compositional depth profiles of the CIGS020 thin film by magnetic sector SIMS using (a) elemental and (b) MCs+ cluster peak intensities

Concentration profiles of elements and MCs+ clusters in magnetic sector SIMS were integrated and compared to ICP-AES results from pieces of the same CIGS films. These results are shown in Table 3. The atomic compositions calculated from the MCs+ cluster peaks of CIGS020, CIGS040, and CIGS050 films are within 1 at% of the ICP-AES results. The results of MCs+-SIMS for the CIGS030 film showed a slightly larger (2 at%) difference from that of the ICP-AES results. Recently, the MCs+-SIMS method has received much attention because of its low sensitivity to changing surface composition and, consequently, has been found to have great advantages in quantification without the need for standards. The SIMS analyses with MCs+ clusters also proved to be a better quantification technique for CIGS absorber films than those with elemental peaks. Cluster peak intensities in the MCs+ depth profile are closer to each other than those in the elemental depth profile, indicating that the cluster ion formation probabilities are more similar, and suppress the matrix effect because of the removal of the ionization probabilities of constituent elements. Improvement in quantitative analysis by the MCs+ clusters of Cu and In in CIGS thin films compared to the individual element analysis was more significant than those by other element clusters. The improvement of quantification from copper and indium clusters is a result of the increased improvement in the molecular ion formation probabilities of CuCs+ and InCs+ ions.

The TOF-SIMS and magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles of the MCs+ clusters for the CIGS thin films are overlapped in Fig. 8. The comparison of both of the atomic distributions exhibited a good agreement, even though they were obtained using two different SIMS instruments with different primary ion energies. Both TOF-SIMS and magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles show similar MCs+ distributions for the CIGS020, CIGS040, and CIGS050 samples as well as for the CIGS010 sample. However, the MCs+ depth profiles of the CIGS030 thin film from two different SIMS instruments were not consistent. As listed in Table 3, the atomic composition results also showed a larger deviation from the ICP-AES result. The MCs+-SIMS method provides an overall more quantitative composition and accurate depth-dependent distribution in the CIGS films, making it useful and convenient for the development of CIGS-based thin-film photovoltaic cells.
Fig. 8
Comparison of TOF-SIMS depth profiles of (a) CIGS010, (b) CIGS020, (c) CIGS030, (d) CIGS040, and (e) CIGS050 thin films with magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles using MCs+ cluster peak intensities

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: SIMS, with its high sensitivity and good depth resolution, is a useful tool for the quantitative analysis of CIGS solar cells. We have shown that the technique of detecting MCs+ ions under Cs+ primary ion bombardment provides an improved SIMS quantitative analysis for the CIGS absorber layer in solar cells. Compositional analyses of CIGS thin films were performed using the MCs+ TOF-SIMS and MCs+ magnetic sector SIMS methods. Quantification of copper, indium, gallium, and selenium contents in the CIGS layer was achieved through the relative sensitivity factor that was based on the formation of MCs+ cluster ions. The MCs+-SIMS method provided more accurate elemental distributions in the CIGS film, especially in the surface region. The MCs+-SIMS technique suppressed the conventional matrix effect in SIMS depth profiling and provided more accurate overall compositions compared to those of elemental SIMS depth profiling.

The MCs+ TOF-SIMS depth profiles were in good agreement with the MCs+ magnetic sector SIMS depth profiles. This approach demonstrated the potential application of the MCs+-SIMS method for the quantitative characterization of multilayer structure thin films in photovoltaic devices.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work was supported by the Korea Institute of Science & Technology (KIST) Institutional Program.
